text: <@U15LJGQPN|arner> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/arner/F3812MMPA/error_on_invoke_-_bluemix____0_6_1.txt|Error on invoke - Bluemix // 0.6.1> and commented: Hi, I'm in the process of upgrading from 0.5 to 0.6.1. Locally, everything works fine. When connected to Bluemix, I can deploy without issues and queries seem to work, but Invokes fail with errors that look like connection issues. Does anyone know why this can happen or what the error messages mean exactly? Thanks!

initial_comment.comment: Hi, I'm in the process of upgrading from 0.5 to 0.6.1. Locally, everything works fine. When connected to Bluemix, I can deploy without issues and queries seem to work, but Invokes fail with errors that look like connection issues. Does anyone know why this can happen or what the error messages mean exactly? Thanks!

text: <@U1NC8D6V9> : I'm not sure if there is an hfc function to query blockheight but its available via REST see <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/docs/API/CoreAPI.md#block>
<@U15LJGQPN> what is the hfc version ? also are you seeing the chaincode container in your Bluemix dashboard ?
0.6.5 - and yes, deployment succeeds and I can see the chaincode on bluemix
<@U13Q594J2> it might be something on the Bluemix side - it seems like my network keeps going down and now I also can’t deploy anymore.
Hi all, is it possible to set user cert attributes after registration is done (through HFC or I suppose chaincode)?  Or is that a registration-time-only facility?

<@U2X9KDDL7> in v0.6 user enrollment cert is only set during memberservice -> enroll(). technically it’s also set when deserializing the member object from FileKeyValStore but that’s all internal and the content came from enroll in the first place. in short, setting ecert is not a public method. what’s your scenario for needing to do this? note that in v1.0 we are making it possible to do this without the memberservice (aka COP), such that you can do something like this:

```
var enrollment = new Enrollment(privateKey, cert);
var user = new Member(name, chain);
user.setEnrollment(enrollment);
user.saveState();
```
this is useful if the app is using an external PKI to generate key pairs and obtain signed certificates

<@U13TWBRBL> I'm exploring if the CA is a reasonable place to manage less-than-permanent attributes, such as issuing/revoking licenses to users to do something which will expire once a particular condition has been reached (preferably in chaincode, but in node.js code as well).  In other words, to see if user cert attributes are mutable with respect to chaincode/app code or not.
